properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring snow continues for southern mountain passes today. An upper trough will persist over BC today resulting in an unstable atmosphere. Convective flurries will continue through tonight and may produce local amounts of 5 to 10 cm over Coquihalla Summit, Allison Pass, Paulson Summit and Kootenay Pass. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-14T22:01:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T14:02:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0443337432.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Is Being Issued By The Weyburn Rural Utility Board
properties.Summary:
Description: The Weyburn Rural Utility Board has issued a precautionary drinking water advisory alert for all the rural water drinking water lines in their system. This advisory is for the entire community and for any individuals who may access water from the Weyburn Rural Utility Board water system. This advisory is in effect due to an upset at the city treatment plant and is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-04-17T17:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Weyburn Rural Utility Board, 2019-04-14T07:36:51-06:00, 6D168AA5-251A-ED7D-21CF-7F9F5471D593
Area: RM's of Weyburn, Brokenshell, Griffin, Lomomd, Wellington, Village of McTaggart
properties.Author: SK Weyburn Rural Utility Board

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major spring storm will hit the province of Quebec from Sunday evening into Monday. 15 to 25 centimetres of heavy snow is expected. This accumulation of snow could result in break tree limbs. The snow may become mixed with ice pellets or freezing rain over some areas Monday. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T01:19:52-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major spring storm will hit the province of Quebec from Sunday evening into Monday. A mixed bag of precipitation could produce water, wet snow and freezing precipitation accumulations on the roads. The heavy snow could result in broken tree limbs. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snowfall possible later today through Monday morning. Snow associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into the region later this afternoon. Snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Monday morning. At this point, it appears that even heavier snowfall will occur from Parry Sound towards Algonquin where a snowfall warning is in effect. Motorists are advised to prepare for potentially hazardous travel conditions later today and tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-14T16:43:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T08:44:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1648042562.2019
Area: West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major spring storm will hit Eastern Quebec Monday through Tuesday. A mixed bag of precipitation could produce water, wet snow and freezing precipitation accumulations on the roads. The heavy snow could result in broken tree limbs. Heavy downpours may cause flash floods and flooding in low lying areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system approaching the province from the southwest is forecast to cross New Brunswick on Monday night before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Over northern New Brunswick, precipitation is expected to begin as a mix of snow and ice pellets tonight. A transition through freezing rain to rain is then expected overnight or Monday morning. The rain is likely to persist into Monday evening before changing back to snow on Monday night as the low pressure system pulls away. Over southern New Brunswick, this system is currently expected to bring predominately rain, beginning tonight. A brief changeover to snow is likely on Monday night as the low moves away. Precipitation will taper off over all areas through the day on Tuesday. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 millimetres are likely across the province, with the possibility of 5 to 10 centimetres of snow for northernmost regions of New Brunswick. Rainfall warnings have been issued for parts of central and northeastern New Brunswick. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-14T21:56:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T13:57:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0774330316.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Fundy National Park, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for Newfoundland early this week. A developing weather system is expected to bring an extended period of strong winds and a variety of precipitation types to the Island for the first half of this week. Precipitation will begin as a mix of snow and ice pellets or as rain over southern and western areas of Newfoundland during the day on Monday. The mixed bag of precipitation will spread to all areas of the Island Monday evening. Generally, rainfall is expected for the South Coast Monday night, while a mixture of snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain is expected for the remainder of Newfoundland. On Tuesday, most areas will experience a slight improvement as precipitation changes to showers or flurries, except over the Great Northern Peninsula, where periods of snow are forecast. Colder air and northerly winds will follow from west to east Tuesday night into Wednesday, changing precipitation back to snow, with the potential for accumulation. Strong easterly winds will develop over most areas Monday night and ease briefly on Tuesday. Gusty northerly winds will then likely follow for Tuesday night into Wednesday. The northerlies should subside Wednesday night as the system finally pulls away. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-14T21:18:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-14T13:19:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1971412253.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A major spring storm will hit the province of Quebec from Sunday evening into Monday. Rainfall amounts of 25 to 40 millimetres are expected. Heavy downpours may cause flash floods and ponding on the roads. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 to 10 millimetres of freezing precipitation is expected overnight tonight into Monday morning. Precipitation will begin as snow this evening before changing to freezing rain. Rain is expected later on. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major storm will hit the Lower North Shore from Monday evening into Tuesday. 30 to 50 centimetres of heavy snow, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T10:06:33-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected for Eastern Ontario. Rain associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into Eastern Ontario by early afternoon and persist until Monday morning. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 mm are expected. With the ground being at least partially frozen across Eastern Ontario, this rainfall may lead to localized flooding in low-lying areas. ### Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected today and tonight. For the higher terrain of the Dundalk Highlands, several hours of freezing rain are possible this afternoon and tonight as temperatures are expected to remain near the freezing mark. Over lower elevations, the freezing rain will switch to rain this afternoon with some areas expected to receive 15 to 25 mm. The freezing rain or rain will change to snow overnight into Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T00:54:12-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant late season snowfall today and tonight. Snow is expected to move into portions of Central Ontario this morning or afternoon. Total snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are likely by Monday morning. The heaviest snow is generally expected in a swath of regions from the northern tip of the Bruce Peninsula towards Algonquin. Some areas immediately south of this swath may change over to rain for a period of time which would result in lesser snowfall accumulations. There will also be a risk of freezing rain in some areas. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T07:16:24-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. A low pressure system approaching the province from the southwest is forecast to cross New Brunswick on Monday night before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Over northern New Brunswick, precipitation is expected to begin as a mix of snow and ice pellets tonight. A transition through freezing rain to rain is then expected overnight or Monday morning. The rain is likely to persist into Monday evening before changing back to snow on Monday night as the low pressure system pulls away. Rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm are forecast for central New Brunswick by late Monday afternoon, with additional amounts expected in the evening prior to the changeover to snow. It is possible that some areas of central New Brunswick will receive a prolonged period of freezing rain tonight into Monday morning, and freezing rain warnings may be issued later today. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T05:57:10-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A messy mix of precipitation on the way for today and tonight. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into portions of Southern Ontario late this morning or this afternoon. A messy mix of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain is possible, although a changeover to rain is anticipated as temperatures will likely rise just above the freezing mark. With temperatures very close to the freezing mark, snowfall and rainfall amounts are highly uncertain. Generally 5 cm or so are likely with 10 to 25 mm of rain also possible. However, if temperatures are slightly colder, snowfall accumulations could be higher. Any places that experience a changeover to rain will change back to snow tonight. Motorists are advised to prepare for potentially hazardous travel conditions today and tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-14T22:56:29-00:00

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely today and tonight over higher elevation areas. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into portions of Central and Eastern Ontario this morning. Precipitation is likely to begin as snow or ice pellets before changing to freezing rain this evening. Several hours of freezing rain are likely over areas of higher elevation before changing back to snow overnight. For lower elevation areas, temperatures will likely rise above the freezing mark later today with 10 to 25 mm of rain possible by Monday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T00:13:58-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall likely today and tonight. Rain associated with an approaching low pressure system will continue today and persist into the overnight hours. Precipitation may start off as snow, ice pellets or freezing rain in a few areas before quickly changing over to rain as temperatures rise. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 30 mm are possible. The ground is still at least partially frozen over portions of Southern Ontario. As a result, the ground will have a limited ability to absorb this rainfall. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. The rain will likely change to snow Monday morning, but accumulations should be light. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-15T00:09:21-00:00
